      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">
      
        <slot></slot>
      <label for="checkbox">
        <slot></slot>

            <div class="container-issue-content">
              <mr-issue-details class="main-item"><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-details {

  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }

                    <kbd><!---->k<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->j<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->prev/next issue in list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->u<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->up to issue list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->r<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->reply to current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->Ctrl+Enter<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->⌘+Enter<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->save issue reply (submit issue on issue filing page)<!----></span>
              <!---->
            </div>
          <!---->
            <div class="keyboard-help-section">
              <span></span><span class="help-title"><!---->Anywhere<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->/<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->focus on the issue search field<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->c<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->compose a new issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->s<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->star the current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->?<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->show this help dialog<!----></span>
              <!---->
            </div>
          <!---->
        </div>
        
          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        <p>
          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        </p>

        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by jorgelo@chromium.org (Oct 16, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      By spinning on the creation of the loop device, followed by spinning on the LOOP_GET_STATUS loop ioctl, the uid 0 code can race the time between the call to LOOP_SET_FD [2] and the actual mount of the loop device [3]. The LOOP_CHANGE_FD ioctl can be used to change the fd of the loop device before mount and therefore allows for control over the arc-obb-mounter root filesystem.<span class="line"><!---->By spinning on the creation of the loop device, followed by spinning on the LOOP_GET_STATUS loop ioctl, the uid 0 code can race the time between the call to LOOP_SET_FD [2] and the actual mount of the loop device [3]. The LOOP_CHANGE_FD ioctl can be used to change the fd of the loop device before mount and therefore allows for control over the arc-obb-mounter root filesystem.<!----></span><br><br>LOOP_CHANGE_FD requires that the new image be of the same type and size, so a new squashfs image was created containing the /etc directory, and an ld.so.preload file pointing to /proc/self/fd/0.<span class="line"><!---->LOOP_CHANGE_FD requires that the new image be of the same type and size, so a new squashfs image was created containing the /etc directory, and an ld.so.preload file pointing to /proc/self/fd/0.<!----></span><br><br>This race is not 100% reliable, however it is cleanly retriable, so the code will retry stop arc-system-mount, start arc-system-mount and spin on the loop device, until the etc directory is present under the arc-obb-mounter rootfs mount at /opt/google/containers/arc-obb-mounter/mountpoints/container-root.<span class="line"><!---->This race is not 100% reliable, however it is cleanly retriable, so the code will retry stop arc-system-mount, start arc-system-mount and spin on the loop device, until the etc directory is present under the arc-obb-mounter rootfs mount at /opt/google/containers/arc-obb-mounter/mountpoints/container-root.<!----></span><br><br>(Note: it's unclear to me right now if this race can be resolved.)<span class="line"><!---->(Note: it's unclear to me right now if this race can be resolved.)<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup.cc#1915<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup.cc#1915"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup.cc#1915<!----></a><br>[2] <span class="line"><!---->[2] <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#392<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#392"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#392<!----></a><br>[3] <span class="line"><!---->[3] <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#421<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#421"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#421<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
      
        
      <div>
        
      </div>
    <mr-description></mr-description>

          Comment 3<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      ereth@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->ereth@google.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>

          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Oct 16, 2020, 11:03 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Oct 16, 2020, 11:03 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        A few comments. I think the race is wider than it looks.<span class="line"><!---->A few comments. I think the race is wider than it looks.<!----></span><br><br>1) The LOOP_CHANGE_FD can be used to change the backing file at any time even long after the mount. However, squashfs seems stubborn about not expecting the underlying data to change so it is hard to get modification to show up. Presumably, with a larger image (eg system or vendor) it would be possible to change some of the backing data that has not been read (recently) and have this new data show up. (sketch: copy system.raw.img to stateful, replace some data blocks, swap backing over to the new non-verified image)<span class="line"><!---->1) The LOOP_CHANGE_FD can be used to change the backing file at any time even long after the mount. However, squashfs seems stubborn about not expecting the underlying data to change so it is hard to get modification to show up. Presumably, with a larger image (eg system or vendor) it would be possible to change some of the backing data that has not been read (recently) and have this new data show up. (sketch: copy system.raw.img to stateful, replace some data blocks, swap backing over to the new non-verified image)<!----></span><br><br>2) The man page mentions that LOOP_CHANGE_FD only works for read only devices. The kernel enforces this, however, LOOP_SET_FD sets the device to be read only if the backing file is read only (or on a read only filesystem). This means we cannot just mark the loop device writable to disable LOOP_CHANGE_FD.<span class="line"><!---->2) The man page mentions that LOOP_CHANGE_FD only works for read only devices. The kernel enforces this, however, LOOP_SET_FD sets the device to be read only if the backing file is read only (or on a read only filesystem). This means we cannot just mark the loop device writable to disable LOOP_CHANGE_FD.<!----></span><br><br>3) The man page of LOOP_CHANGE_FD suggests the new backing must be the same size and the same type, however this is a little misleading. I think the intended meaning was "must be the same [...] if you want your mounted filesystems to have a hope of working so we don't specify the behavior in any other case". (a) The "same type" restriction does not appear to enforced at all. (b) The same effective size is checked but can be worked around fairly trivially. One way is to use the loop device size limit to force a new file to pass the size check then remove the limit and issue LOOP_SET_CAPACITY. Alternatively, you can just make the initial replacement backing the same size and then extend it after the swap.<span class="line"><!---->3) The man page of LOOP_CHANGE_FD suggests the new backing must be the same size and the same type, however this is a little misleading. I think the intended meaning was "must be the same [...] if you want your mounted filesystems to have a hope of working so we don't specify the behavior in any other case". (a) The "same type" restriction does not appear to enforced at all. (b) The same effective size is checked but can be worked around fairly trivially. One way is to use the loop device size limit to force a new file to pass the size check then remove the limit and issue LOOP_SET_CAPACITY. Alternatively, you can just make the initial replacement backing the same size and then extend it after the swap.<!----></span><br><br>4) If someone really does win the race and issue LOOP_CHANGE_FD before the initial mount, we retry with ext4 if squashfs does not work. (<span class="line"><!---->4) If someone really does win the race and issue LOOP_CHANGE_FD before the initial mount, we retry with ext4 if squashfs does not work. (<!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#427<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#427"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#427<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> Although I don't see how that gets anyone further.<span class="line"><!----> Although I don't see how that gets anyone further.<!----></span><br><br>Finally, I can confirm that swapping out the backing with a totally different backing file long after mount results in a block device at /dev/loopX that provides bytes from the new backing. (eg swap backing then compare md5sum of backing file and /dev/loopX) I haven't tried anything tricky with the squashfs images and a late swap of the backing with substantial changes just causes I/O errors.<span class="line"><!---->Finally, I can confirm that swapping out the backing with a totally different backing file long after mount results in a block device at /dev/loopX that provides bytes from the new backing. (eg swap backing then compare md5sum of backing file and /dev/loopX) I haven't tried anything tricky with the squashfs images and a late swap of the backing with substantial changes just causes I/O errors.<!----></span><br><br>See attached for some example code.<span class="line"><!---->See attached for some example code.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
            
      
        
          
          loop-swap.c<b><!---->loop-swap.c<!----></b>
          
        <div class="filename">

        This is an issue in arc-setup. Changing the summary.<span class="line"><!---->This is an issue in arc-setup. Changing the summary.<!----></span><br>Is Security_Severity-High appropraite if the attacker needs to run their code with uid==0?<span class="line"><!---->Is Security_Severity-High appropraite if the attacker needs to run their code with uid==0?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 5<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      jorgelo@chromium.org<a id="user-link" href="/u/2799115547" title="jorgelo@chromium.org"><!---->jorgelo@chromium.org<!----></a>
      jorgelo@chromium.org<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->jorgelo@chromium.org<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 8:51 AM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 8:51 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 8:51 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 8:51 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Yeah, this kind of lies in between High and Medium. On the one hand this is required to go from uid==0 without all caps to uid==0 with all caps, but on the other hand other bugs are needed as well to achieve that escalation.<span class="line"><!---->Yeah, this kind of lies in between High and Medium. On the one hand this is required to go from uid==0 without all caps to uid==0 with all caps, but on the other hand other bugs are needed as well to achieve that escalation.<!----></span><br><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/docs/+/master/security_severity_guidelines.md<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/docs/+/master/security_severity_guidelines.md"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/docs/+/master/security_severity_guidelines.md<!----></a> points out that anything that allows for code execution in a sandboxed process should be marked as High, and anything that allows to read or modify limited amounts of information should be marked as Medium. This bug definitely allows to modify information (since you can swap the loop device's backing), but doesn't really allow for code execution in a sandboxed process without some level of code execution before.<span class="line"><!----> points out that anything that allows for code execution in a sandboxed process should be marked as High, and anything that allows to read or modify limited amounts of information should be marked as Medium. This bug definitely allows to modify information (since you can swap the loop device's backing), but doesn't really allow for code execution in a sandboxed process without some level of code execution before.<!----></span><br><br>We can mark as Medium but it would be good to fix this, since it introduces a huge opportunity for subverting code execution.<span class="line"><!---->We can mark as Medium but it would be good to fix this, since it introduces a huge opportunity for subverting code execution.<!----></span><br><br>Speaking of, do we need LOOP_CHANGE_FD at all? I'd like to block that using SELinux or seccomp globally for every process on the system.<span class="line"><!---->Speaking of, do we need LOOP_CHANGE_FD at all? I'd like to block that using SELinux or seccomp globally for every process on the system.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c7">Comment 7<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 5:36 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

        I vote for globally disabling LOOP_CHANGE_FD.<span class="line"><!---->I vote for globally disabling LOOP_CHANGE_FD.<!----></span><br><br>Without LOOP_CHANGE_FD, the race become a real race against arc-setup. After the LOOP_SET_FD in arc-setup, an attacker must try to call "LOOP_CLR_FD", "LOOP_SET_FD" before arc-setup issues the mount() using this loop.<span class="line"><!---->Without LOOP_CHANGE_FD, the race become a real race against arc-setup. After the LOOP_SET_FD in arc-setup, an attacker must try to call "LOOP_CLR_FD", "LOOP_SET_FD" before arc-setup issues the mount() using this loop.<!----></span><br><br>This, we can close in arc-setup by<span class="line"><!---->This, we can close in arc-setup by<!----></span><br>1) LOOP_SET_FD<span class="line"><!---->1) LOOP_SET_FD<!----></span><br>2) mount()<span class="line"><!---->2) mount()<!----></span><br>At this point, an attacker can no longer issue LOOP_SET_FD as they will get -EBUSY.<span class="line"><!---->At this point, an attacker can no longer issue LOOP_SET_FD as they will get -EBUSY.<!----></span><br>3) LOOP_GET_STATUS64 and compare the lo_inode to the st_ino from fstat(fd).<span class="line"><!---->3) LOOP_GET_STATUS64 and compare the lo_inode to the st_ino from fstat(fd).<!----></span><br><br>If the inodes don't match arc-setup lost the race and we need to try again (or just take our marbles and go home).<span class="line"><!---->If the inodes don't match arc-setup lost the race and we need to try again (or just take our marbles and go home).<!----></span><br><br>I do not think that the above approach works when LOOP_CHANGE_FD is still in the picture though.<span class="line"><!---->I do not think that the above approach works when LOOP_CHANGE_FD is still in the picture though.<!----></span><br><br>With LOOP_CHANGE_FD around we are actually just very lucky that all of the OBB metadata fits entirely in the fixed-size squashfs metadata cache. This cache has no invalidation (since read only filesystem), thus the attack is forced to race against squashfs populating the metadata cache. If mount() above is guaranteed to populate the squashfs metadata cache before returning and we issue LOOP_GET_STATUS things could work but I don't think this is guaranteed.<span class="line"><!---->With LOOP_CHANGE_FD around we are actually just very lucky that all of the OBB metadata fits entirely in the fixed-size squashfs metadata cache. This cache has no invalidation (since read only filesystem), thus the attack is forced to race against squashfs populating the metadata cache. If mount() above is guaranteed to populate the squashfs metadata cache before returning and we issue LOOP_GET_STATUS things could work but I don't think this is guaranteed.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

          Comment 10<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      ereth@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->ereth@google.com<!----></span>

          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Oct 23, 2020, 8:44 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Oct 23, 2020, 8:44 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

        Note so it is not forgotten: In c#7 I said we need to validate the inode has not changed. Of course we need to verify the device id and inode pair to uniquely identify the backing file.<span class="line"><!---->Note so it is not forgotten: In c#7 I said we need to validate the inode has not changed. Of course we need to verify the device id and inode pair to uniquely identify the backing file.<!----></span><br><br>Taking a look at c#8 for what abstractions might fit, we have a few use cases, including mount namespaces and device mapper.<span class="line"><!---->Taking a look at c#8 for what abstractions might fit, we have a few use cases, including mount namespaces and device mapper.<!----></span><br><br>In libcontainer we mount a loop device within a mount namespace using minijail after setting up the loop device. Supporting this requires splitting the verification a little further since the mount does not happen until after minijail_run_*. It should be possible support this by having minijail verify the device id and inode after the mount and before anything executes inside the jail. The best API for this might just be adding explicit loop mount support to minijail that takes an fd to the backing file.<span class="line"><!---->In libcontainer we mount a loop device within a mount namespace using minijail after setting up the loop device. Supporting this requires splitting the verification a little further since the mount does not happen until after minijail_run_*. It should be possible support this by having minijail verify the device id and inode after the mount and before anything executes inside the jail. The best API for this might just be adding explicit loop mount support to minijail that takes an fd to the backing file.<!----></span><br><br>libcontainer also has some device mapper support code. I suspect that this is unused now? However we see device mapper in imageloader and cryptohome as well.<span class="line"><!---->libcontainer also has some device mapper support code. I suspect that this is unused now? However we see device mapper in imageloader and cryptohome as well.<!----></span><br><br>Experimentally, setting up device mapper with a loop as the underlying device marks the loop device as in use. Therefore, we should be able to verify the backing file after the device mapper setup in these cases.<span class="line"><!---->Experimentally, setting up device mapper with a loop as the underlying device marks the loop device as in use. Therefore, we should be able to verify the backing file after the device mapper setup in these cases.<!----></span><br><br>In imageloader, looks like we are trying to put dm-verity over a loop device. In this case, we have a separate way of verifying the contents so we should be okay (unless we use the "check_at_most_once" option). Closing races for this can't hurt though.<span class="line"><!---->In imageloader, looks like we are trying to put dm-verity over a loop device. In this case, we have a separate way of verifying the contents so we should be okay (unless we use the "check_at_most_once" option). Closing races for this can't hurt though.<!----></span><br><br>I have not looked at cryptohome in detail but the use of loop devices looks like it might be used for the ephemeral mount only?<span class="line"><!---->I have not looked at cryptohome in detail but the use of loop devices looks like it might be used for the ephemeral mount only?<!----></span><br><br>All this said I have a few comments now that I have been looking at this for a bit longer.<span class="line"><!---->All this said I have a few comments now that I have been looking at this for a bit longer.<!----></span><br><br>I am surprised by the lack of a CAP_SYS_ADMIN requirement for LOOP_CHANGE_FD. This seems more powerful in some ways than mount and we have a demonstration of how it can be substituted for mount.<span class="line"><!---->I am surprised by the lack of a CAP_SYS_ADMIN requirement for LOOP_CHANGE_FD. This seems more powerful in some ways than mount and we have a demonstration of how it can be substituted for mount.<!----></span><br><br>Verifying the backing c#7 after the mount becomes active suffers from some limitations.<span class="line"><!---->Verifying the backing c#7 after the mount becomes active suffers from some limitations.<!----></span><br><br>(a) The mount happens and the in-kernel filesystem code still processes the "wrong" data. This is something we live with today if we mount removable devices but loop could transform a local-only attack into a remote-exploitable one. (This seems narrow.)<span class="line"><!---->(a) The mount happens and the in-kernel filesystem code still processes the "wrong" data. This is something we live with today if we mount removable devices but loop could transform a local-only attack into a remote-exploitable one. (This seems narrow.)<!----></span><br><br>(b) More importantly, the mount still happens and the "wrong" files become visible in the filesystem even if only briefly. For some attacks this could be sufficient. In particular, we have no way to guarantee that we can unmount the "wrong" mount since an attacker can make the filesystem busy. We can mitigate this partly with lazy unmount but this only makes the window of vulnerability shorter.<span class="line"><!---->(b) More importantly, the mount still happens and the "wrong" files become visible in the filesystem even if only briefly. For some attacks this could be sufficient. In particular, we have no way to guarantee that we can unmount the "wrong" mount since an attacker can make the filesystem busy. We can mitigate this partly with lazy unmount but this only makes the window of vulnerability shorter.<!----></span><br><br>I consider (b) to be fairly troublesome. The arc-setup step in the chain from the parent bug could be repaired even with the verification from c#7. Instead of just racing arc-setup by changing the loop, this step would also need to "capture" the incorrect mount by making it busy. At this point, arc-setup would fail (instead of succeeding as it does now) but the compromised mount would still have been accomplished. With lazy unmount, this race gets shorter since capturing the mount is harder.<span class="line"><!---->I consider (b) to be fairly troublesome. The arc-setup step in the chain from the parent bug could be repaired even with the verification from c#7. Instead of just racing arc-setup by changing the loop, this step would also need to "capture" the incorrect mount by making it busy. At this point, arc-setup would fail (instead of succeeding as it does now) but the compromised mount would still have been accomplished. With lazy unmount, this race gets shorter since capturing the mount is harder.<!----></span><br><br>On kernels 5.2+, (b) can likely be closed by calling fsopen, fsmount, verifying the backing, then calling move_mount to attach at the mount point and make the files visible. Mostly, this just show that a kernel API has actually been implemented that allows us to construct the operation we want but it really doesn't give us much relief here.<span class="line"><!---->On kernels 5.2+, (b) can likely be closed by calling fsopen, fsmount, verifying the backing, then calling move_mount to attach at the mount point and make the files visible. Mostly, this just show that a kernel API has actually been implemented that allows us to construct the operation we want but it really doesn't give us much relief here.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>

      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      sheriffbot<a id="user-link" href="/u/1950284618" title="sheriffbot"><!---->sheriffbot<!----></a>
      sheriffbot<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->sheriffbot<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>

        by

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c11">Comment 11<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Sat, Oct 31, 2020, 12:21 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

        ereth: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. This is a serious vulnerability, and we want to ensure that there's progress.         by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

    <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 2, 2021, 6:23 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c18">Comment 18<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 2, 2021, 6:23 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c18">Comment 18<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 2, 2021, 6:23 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        As alluded to in c#10, my proposal in c#7 is even less valuable than initially thought. Even with LOOP_CHANGE_FD disabled *and* with c#7 a race still exists where the attacker fools us into mounting whatever they desire. I really do not see a way to combine syscalls to build the desired atomic operations.<span class="line"><!---->As alluded to in c#10, my proposal in c#7 is even less valuable than initially thought. Even with LOOP_CHANGE_FD disabled *and* with c#7 a race still exists where the attacker fools us into mounting whatever they desire. I really do not see a way to combine syscalls to build the desired atomic operations.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        I think the consensus is that globally disabling LOOP_CHANGE_FD is good (eg see c#8).<span class="line"><!---->I think the consensus is that globally disabling LOOP_CHANGE_FD is good (eg see c#8).<!----></span><br><br>Are we okay with just adding a SECCOMP filter during init and letting later filters layer on after? It's slightly wasteful since lots of programs should be running with a  SECCOMP filter blocking most ioctls anyway but we are talking a few extra comparisons on whole context switch. I guess we can try it out at least.<span class="line"><!---->Are we okay with just adding a SECCOMP filter during init and letting later filters layer on after? It's slightly wasteful since lots of programs should be running with a  SECCOMP filter blocking most ioctls anyway but we are talking a few extra comparisons on whole context switch. I guess we can try it out at least.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>

        for LitElement.

    <mr-issue-page issueclosed=""><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>

        Description #1 by jorgelo@chromium.org (Oct 16, 2020)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by jorgelo@chromium.org (Oct 16, 2020)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by jorgelo@chromium.org (Oct 16, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by jorgelo@chromium.org (Oct 16, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      By spinning on the creation of the loop device, followed by spinning on the LOOP_GET_STATUS loop ioctl, the uid 0 code can race the time between the call to LOOP_SET_FD [2] and the actual mount of the loop device [3]. The LOOP_CHANGE_FD ioctl can be used to change the fd of the loop device before mount and therefore allows for control over the arc-obb-mounter root filesystem.<span class="line"><!---->By spinning on the creation of the loop device, followed by spinning on the LOOP_GET_STATUS loop ioctl, the uid 0 code can race the time between the call to LOOP_SET_FD [2] and the actual mount of the loop device [3]. The LOOP_CHANGE_FD ioctl can be used to change the fd of the loop device before mount and therefore allows for control over the arc-obb-mounter root filesystem.<!----></span><br><br>LOOP_CHANGE_FD requires that the new image be of the same type and size, so a new squashfs image was created containing the /etc directory, and an ld.so.preload file pointing to /proc/self/fd/0.<span class="line"><!---->LOOP_CHANGE_FD requires that the new image be of the same type and size, so a new squashfs image was created containing the /etc directory, and an ld.so.preload file pointing to /proc/self/fd/0.<!----></span><br><br>This race is not 100% reliable, however it is cleanly retriable, so the code will retry stop arc-system-mount, start arc-system-mount and spin on the loop device, until the etc directory is present under the arc-obb-mounter rootfs mount at /opt/google/containers/arc-obb-mounter/mountpoints/container-root.<span class="line"><!---->This race is not 100% reliable, however it is cleanly retriable, so the code will retry stop arc-system-mount, start arc-system-mount and spin on the loop device, until the etc directory is present under the arc-obb-mounter rootfs mount at /opt/google/containers/arc-obb-mounter/mountpoints/container-root.<!----></span><br><br>(Note: it's unclear to me right now if this race can be resolved.)<span class="line"><!---->(Note: it's unclear to me right now if this race can be resolved.)<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup.cc#1915<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup.cc#1915"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup.cc#1915<!----></a><br>[2] <span class="line"><!---->[2] <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#392<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#392"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#392<!----></a><br>[3] <span class="line"><!---->[3] <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#421<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#421"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#421<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 3<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      ereth@google.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/64821336" title="ereth@google.com"><!---->ereth@google.com<!----></a>
      ereth@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->ereth@google.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Fri, Oct 16, 2020, 11:03 PM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Oct 16, 2020, 11:03 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Oct 16, 2020, 11:03 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Oct 16, 2020, 11:03 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        A few comments. I think the race is wider than it looks.<span class="line"><!---->A few comments. I think the race is wider than it looks.<!----></span><br><br>1) The LOOP_CHANGE_FD can be used to change the backing file at any time even long after the mount. However, squashfs seems stubborn about not expecting the underlying data to change so it is hard to get modification to show up. Presumably, with a larger image (eg system or vendor) it would be possible to change some of the backing data that has not been read (recently) and have this new data show up. (sketch: copy system.raw.img to stateful, replace some data blocks, swap backing over to the new non-verified image)<span class="line"><!---->1) The LOOP_CHANGE_FD can be used to change the backing file at any time even long after the mount. However, squashfs seems stubborn about not expecting the underlying data to change so it is hard to get modification to show up. Presumably, with a larger image (eg system or vendor) it would be possible to change some of the backing data that has not been read (recently) and have this new data show up. (sketch: copy system.raw.img to stateful, replace some data blocks, swap backing over to the new non-verified image)<!----></span><br><br>2) The man page mentions that LOOP_CHANGE_FD only works for read only devices. The kernel enforces this, however, LOOP_SET_FD sets the device to be read only if the backing file is read only (or on a read only filesystem). This means we cannot just mark the loop device writable to disable LOOP_CHANGE_FD.<span class="line"><!---->2) The man page mentions that LOOP_CHANGE_FD only works for read only devices. The kernel enforces this, however, LOOP_SET_FD sets the device to be read only if the backing file is read only (or on a read only filesystem). This means we cannot just mark the loop device writable to disable LOOP_CHANGE_FD.<!----></span><br><br>3) The man page of LOOP_CHANGE_FD suggests the new backing must be the same size and the same type, however this is a little misleading. I think the intended meaning was "must be the same [...] if you want your mounted filesystems to have a hope of working so we don't specify the behavior in any other case". (a) The "same type" restriction does not appear to enforced at all. (b) The same effective size is checked but can be worked around fairly trivially. One way is to use the loop device size limit to force a new file to pass the size check then remove the limit and issue LOOP_SET_CAPACITY. Alternatively, you can just make the initial replacement backing the same size and then extend it after the swap.<span class="line"><!---->3) The man page of LOOP_CHANGE_FD suggests the new backing must be the same size and the same type, however this is a little misleading. I think the intended meaning was "must be the same [...] if you want your mounted filesystems to have a hope of working so we don't specify the behavior in any other case". (a) The "same type" restriction does not appear to enforced at all. (b) The same effective size is checked but can be worked around fairly trivially. One way is to use the loop device size limit to force a new file to pass the size check then remove the limit and issue LOOP_SET_CAPACITY. Alternatively, you can just make the initial replacement backing the same size and then extend it after the swap.<!----></span><br><br>4) If someone really does win the race and issue LOOP_CHANGE_FD before the initial mount, we retry with ext4 if squashfs does not work. (<span class="line"><!---->4) If someone really does win the race and issue LOOP_CHANGE_FD before the initial mount, we retry with ext4 if squashfs does not work. (<!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#427<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#427"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform2/+/refs/heads/master/arc/setup/arc_setup_util.cc#427<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> Although I don't see how that gets anyone further.<span class="line"><!----> Although I don't see how that gets anyone further.<!----></span><br><br>Finally, I can confirm that swapping out the backing with a totally different backing file long after mount results in a block device at /dev/loopX that provides bytes from the new backing. (eg swap backing then compare md5sum of backing file and /dev/loopX) I haven't tried anything tricky with the squashfs images and a late swap of the backing with substantial changes just causes I/O errors.<span class="line"><!---->Finally, I can confirm that swapping out the backing with a totally different backing file long after mount results in a block device at /dev/loopX that provides bytes from the new backing. (eg swap backing then compare md5sum of backing file and /dev/loopX) I haven't tried anything tricky with the squashfs images and a late swap of the backing with substantial changes just causes I/O errors.<!----></span><br><br>See attached for some example code.<span class="line"><!---->See attached for some example code.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
            
      
        
          
          loop-swap.c<b><!---->loop-swap.c<!----></b>

          Comment 4<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="Last visit > 30 days ago" hidden="">schedule</i>

          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 7:05 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 7:05 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
      
        
          Summary:<strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          arc-setup: ArcMounterImpl::LoopMount() can be raced
          (was: arc-obb-mounter can be raced)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          arc-setup: ArcMounterImpl::LoopMount() can be raced
          (was: arc-obb-mounter can be raced)
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        This is an issue in arc-setup. Changing the summary.<span class="line"><!---->This is an issue in arc-setup. Changing the summary.<!----></span><br>Is Security_Severity-High appropraite if the attacker needs to run their code with uid==0?<span class="line"><!---->Is Security_Severity-High appropraite if the attacker needs to run their code with uid==0?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Yeah, this kind of lies in between High and Medium. On the one hand this is required to go from uid==0 without all caps to uid==0 with all caps, but on the other hand other bugs are needed as well to achieve that escalation.<span class="line"><!---->Yeah, this kind of lies in between High and Medium. On the one hand this is required to go from uid==0 without all caps to uid==0 with all caps, but on the other hand other bugs are needed as well to achieve that escalation.<!----></span><br><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/docs/+/master/security_severity_guidelines.md<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/docs/+/master/security_severity_guidelines.md"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/docs/+/master/security_severity_guidelines.md<!----></a> points out that anything that allows for code execution in a sandboxed process should be marked as High, and anything that allows to read or modify limited amounts of information should be marked as Medium. This bug definitely allows to modify information (since you can swap the loop device's backing), but doesn't really allow for code execution in a sandboxed process without some level of code execution before.<span class="line"><!----> points out that anything that allows for code execution in a sandboxed process should be marked as High, and anything that allows to read or modify limited amounts of information should be marked as Medium. This bug definitely allows to modify information (since you can swap the loop device's backing), but doesn't really allow for code execution in a sandboxed process without some level of code execution before.<!----></span><br><br>We can mark as Medium but it would be good to fix this, since it introduces a huge opportunity for subverting code execution.<span class="line"><!---->We can mark as Medium but it would be good to fix this, since it introduces a huge opportunity for subverting code execution.<!----></span><br><br>Speaking of, do we need LOOP_CHANGE_FD at all? I'd like to block that using SELinux or seccomp globally for every process on the system.<span class="line"><!---->Speaking of, do we need LOOP_CHANGE_FD at all? I'd like to block that using SELinux or seccomp globally for every process on the system.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1139417#c7">Comment 7<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 19, 2020, 5:36 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
